III.	Facility Identification
The Peacock Engineering facility is located at 720 Center Street in Carol Stream, Illinois.  Peacock Engineering is a contract food packaging and co-manufacturing facility that provides manufacturing / processing support, secondary packaging and shipping to suppliers and distribution centers. 

The NAICS code for the facility is 31199.  A large portion of the facility is refrigerated to preserve products for packaging and distribution.   

The facility uses ammonia for refrigeration, and is regulated under 40 CFR Part 68, the EPA RMP Rule. There is one (1) refrigeration system onsite that is used for refrigerating coolers and freezers throughout the facility. 

The amount of ammonia currently onsite has been estimated at approximately 23,000 pounds.  The refrigeration system is used to cool freezers, coolers, production rooms, and docks.  This refrigeration system uses ammonia refrigerant in a two (2) stage evaporation/condensation cycle.  The ammonia related equipment could be divided into two sections. The "low stage" equipment contains (1) -10 Freezer Evaporator, (1) Bologna Freezer Evaporator, (1) Cheese Freezer Evaporator, Low Temperature Pump Package (PR-2), (1) Oil Pot and (1) Booster Compressor.  

The "high stage" equipment contains (6) Production Room Evaporators, (3) Ultima B Room Evaporators, (3) Ultima A Room Evaporators, (3) Cooler 1 Evaporators, (2) Dock 1 Evaporators, (4) Oswald Room Evaporators, (2) Yellow Room Evaporators, (5) Secondary Packaging Room Evaporators, (2) Viking Room Evaporators, (3) Cooler 2 Evaporators, (2) Dock 2 Evaporators, (8) Cooler 3 Evaporators, (2) Dock 3 Evaporators, (1) Bread Room Evaporator, (2) KWT-3 Room Evaporators, (2) CP-13 Room Evaporators,

(4) CP-13-CP-14 Secondary Room Evaporators, (11) Make-up Air Units, (1) Glycol Heat Exchanger, (1) High Temperature Pump Package (PR-1), (1) Oil Pot, and (4) High Stage Compressors.  The "high-pressure" equipment also includes (3) Evaporative Condensers and (1) Thermosyphon/High Pressure Receiver (HPR-1), (1) High Pressure Receiver (HPR-2) and associated piping/valves.

An aerial map identifying the site location is included as Appendix A.

Appendix B consists of the RMP*Submit Printout and contains additional information on the alternative release scenario.  Appendix D consists of the offsite consequence analysis data and maps for the alternative release scenario. 

VI.	General Accidental Release Prevention Program
A prevention program has been developed to minimize the risk of hazardous chemical releases in accordance with the OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (29 CFR 1910.119) and the EPA Risk Management Program.   

This prevention program covers those processes that handle ammonia above the threshold quantity for both PSM and RMP rules. The next audit of the PSM program will occur by November 11, 2013, in compliance with the requirement to conduct PSM audits every three years.  The elements of the PSM / Program 3 prevention program and a brief description are listed below.
¿	Employee Participation - Peacock Engineering has developed a site-specific employee participation plan that ensures employees and their representatives are consulted when conducting and developing process hazard analyses and other information required to be developed under the PSM/RMP regulation.  In addition, the employee participatio

n program will ensure employees and their representatives have access to process hazard analyses and all other information required to be developed under PSM/RMP.  
¿	Process Safety Information - Peacock Engineering maintains a site-specific PSI program that ensures information pertaining to the hazards, technology, and equipment of the process are properly developed and maintained. Process safety information for the ammonia process has been compiled and was last reviewed on August 9, 2011.
¿	Process Hazard Analysis - Peacock Engineering has developed a site-specific PHA program that ensured a PHA was conducted initially, at a minimum of every five (5) years, and whenever a change is significant enough to require a change in PSI.  In addition, this program ensures PHAs are conducted in accordance with OSHA and EPA regulations and ensures findings and recommendations of PHAs are properly documented. Peacock Engineering conducted a thorough, initial, PHA study for the refrigeration system during August 2011.
¿	Operating Procedures - Peacock Engineering has developed a site-specific procedure that ensures operating procedures provide clear instruction for different phases of process operations and ensures they are properly maintained.  Peacock Engineering developed initial operating procedures for the refrigeration system during February 2007.  Annually, the operating procedures are reviewed and certified as accurate.
 
¿	Training - Peacock Engineering has developed a site-specific training procedure that ensures employees operating the ammonia process have the knowledge to safely operate the process, are aware of the potential hazards of the process, and understand the causes of process problems.
¿	Management of Change - Peacock Engineering has developed a site-specific management of change procedure that ensures changes (except for replacement in kind) to the ammonia process, such as additions of new equipment or changes in operating, maintenance, or other proc

e audit will be conducted by November 11, 2013.  
¿	Hot Work Permits - Peacock Engineering has developed a best management practice for hot work.  Peacock Engineering's hot work permit procedures for the refrigeration system were reviewed on November 11, 2010.
 

VII.	Five-Year Accident History
The Peacock Engineering facility has not experienced an accidental anhydrous ammonia release, which resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

VIII.	Emergency Response Program
Peacock Engineering has developed an Emergency Response Plan (ERP) to ensure that in the event of an emergency the facility personnel are aware of the appropriate actions to take and authorities to contact in order to mitigate the effects of a release. 

Peacock Engineering has conducted emergency drills as a training tool to provide employees proper evacuation procedures and has interacted (i.e. onsite meetings) with the Carol Stream Fire Department. 

Peacock Engineering has coordinated their ERP with the Carol Stream Fire Department.  This coordination effort includes providing the agency with a copy of our ERP, and providing a site diagram and hazardous material information, meeting with Carol Stream Fire Department personnel to discuss the facilities operations/processes, and encouraging periodic on-site inspections and coordination with Carol Stream Fire Department personnel.

Peacock Engineering's maintenance department will have designated personnel as members of the emergency response team and will be responsible for investigating and assisting the Carol Stream Fire Department (if necessary) with response to accidental releases of ammonia. 

The facility has four (4) windsocks onsite for use in determining wind direction in the event of an ammonia release and evacuation of the building.  The windsocks are located on the Southeast, Southwest, a

nd Northeast corners building, as well as on the west side of the building near the engine room. 

The current Material Safety Data Sheet (MSDS) for anhydrous ammonia is included in Appendix E. 

IX.	Emergency Communications
The telephone numbers of agencies and plant personnel that may be contacted in case of an emergency are available onsite.
 

X.	Planned Changes to Improve Safety
Chemical safety is an important part of Peacock Engineering operations. Peacock Engineering is currently implementing their Process Safety Management Program. Continuous improvement in safety is an important goal for Peacock Engineering.  

XI.	Management Program
Peacock Engineering has updated a management system to oversee the implementation of the risk management program elements.  This system has assigned qualified person(s) (or position) to assist in the development, implementation, and integration of the risk management program elements.  If any portion of the program is delegated to others, the names or positions of those individuals will be documented and the lines of authority defined through an organization chart or similar document.  Currently, Gary Home, Refrigeration Engineer, is the PSM / RMP Coordinator and Brain Gross, Plant Manager, is responsible for implementation of the overall Risk Management Program.
